Introduction

The embryonic stage of development (ie, weeks 3-8 of gestation) is a critical time for organogenesis (

figure 1
).  Gastrulation marks the beginning of the embryonic stage of development and establishes the 3 primary germ layers (trilaminar disk) from which all tissues and organs are derived: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm (
figure 2
).



Components of the gastrointestinal (GI) system are derived from each of these germ layers (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
), as follows:



  • Endoderm:  Gives rise to the epithelial lining of the GI tract (from the pharynx cranially to the rectum caudally), liver, and pancreas.
  • Mesoderm:  Gives rise to the connective tissue, smooth muscle, and blood vessels of the GI tract as well as the peritoneum and spleen.
  • Ectoderm:  Gives rise to the epithelial lining of the oral cavity and salivary glands.  The neural crest is derived from ectoderm and gives rise to neural ganglia, including enteric ganglion cells.  Failure of neural crest cell migration results in Hirschsprung disease, a condition in which the aganglionic sigmoid colon/rectum causes functional obstruction (
    figure 3
    ).

Formation of the primitive gut tube



Following gastrulation, the flat trilaminar disc elongates and folds on itself, forming the primitive gut tube, which is divided into 3 segments: foregut, midgut, and hindgut.  The midgut is open and remains connected to the yolk sac via the vitelline duct, which will eventually regress as the embryo grows (

figure 4
).  Failure of the vitelline duct to completely regress results in Meckel diverticulum, an ileal outpouching with a fibrous connection to the umbilicus (
figure 5
).



Each segment of the gut tube is supplied by its own artery and gives rise to important anatomic structures.

Foregut development



The foregut is supplied by the celiac artery, and its cephalic end forms the oropharyngeal membrane, which will become the opening of the oral cavity.  Derivatives of the foregut include the following structures:



  • Pharynx.
  • Esophagus:  The tracheoesophageal septum divides the ventral respiratory diverticulum, which gives rise to the trachea and lung buds, from the dorsal esophagus in early embryogenesis.  Incomplete separation of the esophagus and trachea results in esophageal atresia and/or tracheoesophageal fistula (
    figure 6
    ).  The esophagus is initially short but elongates as the heart and lungs descend.
  • Stomach:  Forms as a dilation of the foregut that rotates 90 degrees clockwise due to differential growth rates of fetal tissues.  The left side becomes anterior, and the right side becomes posterior.  The posterior wall grows faster than the anterior wall, forming the greater curvature along the right side of the stomach.
  • Proximal duodenum:  As the stomach rotates, the duodenum forms a C-shaped loop and rotates to the right.  As fetal abdominal contents undergo rapid growth, the duodenum shifts into the retroperitoneum.  In addition, rapid cellular proliferation obliterates the lumen of the duodenum, which subsequently recanalizes.
  • Liver and gallbladder:  The hepatic diverticulum (ie, liver bud) develops from the distal foregut.  The connection between the foregut and hepatic diverticulum forms the bile duct, which gives rise to the gallbladder and cystic duct.
  • Pancreas:  The dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds form from the developing duodenum.  As the duodenum rotates to the right, the ventral pancreatic bud rotates dorsally and fuses with the dorsal pancreatic bud (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: video 1
    ).  The ventral bud forms the uncinate process and part of the head of the pancreas, and the dorsal bud forms the remaining segment.  Improper rotation and/or fusion of the pancreatic buds results in annular pancreas (
    figure 7
    ).

Midgut development



The midgut is supplied by the superior mesenteric artery, and its derivatives include the following structures:



  • Distal duodenum:  The midgut gives rise to the duodenum distal to the sphincter of Oddi, where the common bile duct enters the duodenum.
  • Jejunum.
  • Ileum.
  • Cecum.
  • Appendix.
  • Ascending colon.
  • Proximal transverse colon.


The abdominal cavity cannot accommodate the rapidly elongating intestinal loop, and there is a brief period in which the midgut herniates through the umbilical ring (ie, physiologic herniation) and rotates 90 degrees counterclockwise.  The midgut subsequently returns to the abdominal cavity and rotates an additional 180 degrees counterclockwise (ie, 270 degrees total).  The rotation and final positioning of the intestinal loops within the abdominal cavity create a wide mesenteric base that extends from the duodenojejunal flexure in the left upper quadrant to the cecum in the right upper quadrant.



Failure of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity results in omphalocele (

figure 8
).  In addition, failure of the midgut to completely rotate 270 degrees results in malrotation, which can lead to intestinal obstruction and/or volvulus.  In cases of intestinal malrotation, the duodenojejunal flexure and jejunal loops lie on the right (instead of the left) side of the abdominal cavity, resulting in a narrow, mobilic mesenteric base that is prone to twisting around the superior mesenteric artery (ie, volvulus) (
ðŸ“Š View Table: video 2
).

Hindgut development



The hindgut is supplied by the inferior mesenteric artery and includes the following derivative structures:



  • Distal transverse colon.
  • Descending colon.
  • Sigmoid colon.
  • Rectum.
  • Proximal anal canal.


The hindgut terminates in the cloacal membrane.  The urorectal septum descends and fuses with the cloacal membrane, separating the anterior urogenital sinus from the posterior hindgut.  The cloacal membrane will eventually disintegrate to form the opening of the anus and genital tract.

Summary



The gastrointestinal tract is derived from the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm of the trilaminar disc as it folds and forms a blind-ending tube.  The tube is divided according to its arterial supply from the aorta, as follows: The celiac artery supplies the foregut, the superior mesenteric artery supplies the midgut, and the inferior mesenteric artery supplies the hindgut.  Each segment gives rise to important anatomic structures, and improper development can lead to clinically significant congenital anomalies.
